page.title: 04LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The public house at the Offenham ferry crossing is named 'The Bridge' although no bridge now exists. The public house has in the past been called 'The Waterloo Tavern' but the present name was introduced to commemorate the footbridge which existed there from the Middle Ages but which was demolished at least 200years ago. During the great drought of 1982 the water level dropped to the lowest ever recorded and the Medieval foundation stones of the pillars became clearly visible. Before the footbridge had been built there had obviously been a ford in existance as depicted by the name of the Evesham side of the river-Twyford. The river depth at this point is only some 5ft but it plunges to depths of 15 or 20ft withtin 100 yards.
